title.narrative: 2.2 NUTRITION SERVICE DELIVERY

description.narrative: Improved, integrated, quality basic nutrition services for children and pregnant and lactating women, including Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs), are available., which contributes to Early Childhood Development, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2020, increased proportions of girls and boys under the age of 5 years and women have equitable access to and use essential services and adopt optimal nutrition practices to reduce all forms of malnutrition, with a focus on vulnerable Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and emergency- affected communities

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Improved, integrated, quality basic nutrition services for children and pregnant and lactating women, including IDPs, are available.

description.narrative: The Post Gu Assessment, 2020 showed;Global Acute Malnutrition (GAM);at 11.8%, a marginal decrease from 13.8% (Post Gu;2019). UNICEF reached 245,296;children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM); 144% of the burden.;Some 24,000 children with moderate acute malnutrition (MAM) were treated using simplified protocol. Over 90% of nutrition sites reported zero ‘stock-out’ of ready to use therapeutic Foods (RUTF), with a 28% reduction in supplies released in 2020 vs 2019;showing increased efficiency of supply;management.;More than 95% of districts in Somalia have SAM treatment services, an improvement from 65% in 2017.; | Status:Met | As-of Date:04/01/2021
